div.p: Greetings in the Lord, I wrote two letters to you and to Mr. Theodor, which I enclosed in a container with peas, and the carrier deceived me nicely, who left my container in Basel without my knowledge; but soon you will have it, in which you have Gerbel's book along with some other things that pertain to your wife and Frisius.
You will find the news I had in the written letters. The plague is spreading little among us.
May the Lord increase our faith. What are you now writing, dear Bullinger, for the benefit of the church?

Great evils threaten the church, and if it were allowed to predict, the greatest would be from hypocrites who act among us. There is a great and abundant crop of false brothers everywhere, whom the Lord will eventually destroy.

King Ferdinand has begun to promulgate the Turkish tax. There is a rumor that the Maltese lords have suffered a great defeat by Dragut, the king of Africa, and that Maximilian is in great danger in Spain. Various rumors are spread about these matters; but we have nothing certain. I wanted to write these few things to you, so that this young man, who visited me and offered himself to deliver letters to you, would not return to you empty-handed.
My wife sends your wife a pair of knives for a fair and asks that she consider it kindly. They are included in the container, etc.
To the uniquely learned and pious Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church in Zurich.
